  <TR>
    <TD vAlign=top noWrap><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>(1)</FONT></TD>
    <TD vAlign=top noWrap><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </FONT></TD>
    <TD width="100%"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Except as noted, each of the
      directors has been employed by his or her present employer (or a
      subsidiary) in an executive capacity for at least five
  years.</FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<P align=center><B><FONT face="Times New Roman">13</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>

<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>
<P align=center><FONT STYLE="font: x-small Times New Roman"><B>I</B></FONT><B><FONT STYLE="font-size: xx-small">NFORMATION</FONT><FONT STYLE="font-size: x-small"> C</FONT><FONT STYLE="font-size: xx-small">ONCERNING THE</FONT><FONT STYLE="font-size: x-small"> B</FONT><FONT STYLE="font-size: xx-small">OARD</FONT><FONT STYLE="font-size: xx-small"> OF</FONT><FONT STYLE="font-size: x-small"> D</FONT><FONT STYLE="font-size: xx-small">IRECTORS</FONT></B></P>
<P align=justify><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>C</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>OMMITTEES</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>
OF</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1> THE </FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>B</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>OARD</FONT></B></P>
<P align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>The Board of
Directors has a number of standing committees including Audit, Compensation, and
Corporate Governance Committees. All standing committees are composed
exclusively of independent directors. All Board committees have charters that
can be found on our corporate website at www.thekrogerco.com under
</FONT><I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Guidelines on Issues of Corporate
Governance</FONT></I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>. During 2011, the Audit Committee
met five times, the Compensation Committee met five times, and the Corporate
Governance Committee met two times. Committee memberships are shown on pages 8
through 13 of this Proxy Statement. The Audit Committee reviews financial
reporting and accounting matters pursuant to its charter and selects our
independent accountants. The Compensation Committee recommends for determination
by the independent members of our Board the compensation of the Chief Executive
Officer, determines the compensation of Kroger&#146;s other senior management, and
administers some of our incentive programs. Additional information on the
Compensation Committee&#146;s processes and procedures for consideration of executive
compensation are addressed in the Compensation Discussion and Analysis below.
The Corporate Governance Committee develops criteria for selecting and retaining
members of the Board, seeks out qualified candidates for the Board, and reviews
the performance of the Board, and along with the other independent board
members, the CEO.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>The Corporate Governance Committee will consider shareholder
recommendations for nominees for membership on the Board of Directors.
Recommendations relating to our annual meeting in June 2013, together with a
description of the proposed nominee&#146;s qualifications, background and experience,
must be submitted in writing to Paul W. Heldman, Secretary, and received at our
executive offices not later than January 11, 2013. The shareholder also should
indicate the number of shares beneficially owned by the shareholder. The
Secretary will forward the information to the Corporate Governance Committee for
its consideration. The Committee will use the same criteria in evaluating
candidates submitted by shareholders as it uses in evaluating candidates
identified by the Committee. These criteria are:</FONT></P>
<UL style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt"><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Demonstrated ability in fields considered to be of
  value in the deliberations of the Board, including</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>business management, public service, education, science, law, and
  government;</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Highest standards of personal character and
  conduct;</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Willingness to fulfill the obligations of
  directors and to make the contribution of which he or she is capable,</FONT>
  <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>including regular attendance and participation at
  Board and committee meetings, and preparation for all</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>meetings, including review of all meeting materials provided in advance
  of the meeting; and</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Ability to understand the perspectives of Kroger&#146;s
  customers, taking into consideration the diversity of</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>our customers, including regional and geographic differences.</FONT>
  </LI></UL>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>Racial, ethnic, and gender diversity is an important element in promoting
full, open, and balanced deliberations of issues presented to the Board, and is
considered by the Corporate Governance Committee. Some consideration also is
given to the geographic location of director candidates in order to provide a
reasonable distribution of members from the operating areas of the
Company.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>The Corporate Governance Committee typically recruits candidates for
Board membership through its own efforts and through suggestions from other
directors and shareholders. The Committee on occasion has retained an outside
search firm to assist in identifying and recruiting Board candidates who meet
the criteria established by the Committee.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><STRONG>C</STRONG></FONT><STRONG><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>ORPORATE</FONT><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2> G</FONT><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>OVERNANCE</FONT></STRONG></P>
<P align=justify><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>The Board of Directors has adopted
</FONT><I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Guidelines on Issues of Corporate
Governance</FONT></I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>. These </FONT><I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Guidelines</FONT></I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>, which include copies of
the current charters for the Audit, Compensation, and Corporate Governance
Committees, and the other committees of the Board of Directors, are available on
our corporate website at www.thekrogerco.com. Shareholders may obtain a copy of
the </FONT><I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Guidelines</FONT></I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2> by making a written request to Kroger&#146;s Secretary at our executive
offices.</FONT></P>
<P align=center><B><FONT face="Times New Roman">14</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>

<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>
<P align=justify><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>I</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>NDEPENDENCE</FONT></B></P>
<P align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>The Board of
Directors has determined that all of the directors, with the exception of
Messrs. Dillon and McMullen, have no material relationships with Kroger and,
therefore, are independent for purposes of the New York Stock Exchange listing
standards. The Board made its determination based on information furnished by
all members regarding their relationships with Kroger. After reviewing the
information, the Board determined that all of the non-employee directors were
independent because (i) they all satisfied the independence standards set forth
in Rule 10A-3 of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, (ii) they all satisfied
the criteria for independence set forth in Rule 303A.02 of the New York Stock
Exchange Listed Company Manual, and (iii) other than business transactions
between Kroger and entities with which the directors are affiliated, the value
of which falls below the thresholds identified by the New York Stock Exchange
listing standards, none had any material relationships with us except for those
arising directly from their performance of services as a director for
Kroger.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>L</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>EAD</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>
D</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>IRECTOR</FONT></B></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>The Lead Director presides over all executive sessions of the
non-management directors, serves as the principal liaison between the
non-management directors and management, and consults with the Chairman
regarding information to be sent to the Board, meeting agendas, and establishing
meeting schedules. Unless otherwise determined by the Board, the chair of the
Corporate Governance Committee is designated as the Lead Director.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>A</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>UDIT</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>
C</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>OMMITTEE</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2> E</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>XPERTISE</FONT></B></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>The Board of Directors has determined that Susan M. Phillips and Ronald
L. Sargent, independent directors who are members of the Audit Committee, are
&#147;audit committee financial experts&#148; as defined by applicable SEC regulations and
that all members of the Audit Committee are &#147;financially literate&#148; as that term
is used in the NYSE listing standards.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>C</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>ODE</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>
OF </FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>E</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>THICS</FONT></B></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>The Board of Directors has adopted </FONT><I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>The
Kroger Co. Policy on Business Ethics</FONT></I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>,
applicable to all officers, employees and members of the Board of Directors,
including Kroger&#146;s principal executive, financial, and accounting officers. The
</FONT><I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Policy</FONT></I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2> is
available on our corporate website at www.thekrogerco.com. Shareholders may
obtain a copy of the </FONT><I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Policy</FONT></I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2> by making a written request to Kroger&#146;s Secretary at our
executive offices.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>C</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>OMMUNICATIONS</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>
WITH</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1> THE </FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>B</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>OARD</FONT></B></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>The Board has established two separate mechanisms for shareholders and
interested parties to communicate with the Board. Any shareholder or interested
party who has concerns regarding accounting, improper use of Kroger assets, or
ethical improprieties may report these concerns via the toll-free hotline
(800-689-4609) or email address (helpline@kroger.com) established by the Board&#146;s
Audit Committee. The concerns are investigated by Kroger&#146;s Vice President of
Auditing and reported to the Audit Committee as deemed appropriate by the Vice
President of Auditing.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>Shareholders or interested parties also may communicate with the Board in
writing directed to Kroger&#146;s Secretary at our executive offices. The Secretary
will consider the nature of the communication and determine whether to forward
the communication to the chair of the Corporate Governance Committee.
Communications relating to personnel issues or our ordinary business operations,
or seeking to do business with us, will be forwarded to the business unit of
Kroger that the Secretary deems appropriate. All other communications will be
forwarded to the chair of the Corporate Governance Committee for further
consideration. The chair of the Corporate Governance Committee will take such
action as he or she deems appropriate, which may include referral to the
Corporate Governance Committee or the entire Board.</FONT></P>
<P align=center><B><FONT face="Times New Roman">15</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>

<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>
<P align=justify><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>A</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>TTENDANCE</FONT></B></P>
<P align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>The Board of
Directors met five times in 2011. During 2011, all incumbent directors attended
at least 75% of the aggregate number of meetings of the Board and committees on
which that director served. Members of the Board are expected to use their best
efforts to attend all annual meetings of shareholders. All
fourteen</FONT><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2> </FONT></B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>members of the Board attended last year&#146;s annual meeting.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>C</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>OMPENSATION</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>
C</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>ONSULTANTS</FONT></B></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>The Compensation Committee directly engages a compensation consultant
from Mercer Human Resource Consulting to advise the Committee in the design of
compensation for executive officers. In 2011, Kroger paid that consultant
$248,517 for work performed for the Committee. Kroger, on management&#146;s
recommendation, retained the parent and affiliated companies of Mercer Human
Resource Consulting to provide other services for Kroger in 2011, for which
Kroger paid $2,523,893. These other services primarily related to insurance
claims (for which Kroger was reimbursed by insurance carriers as claims were
adjusted), insurance brokerage and bonding commissions, and pension consulting.
Kroger also made payments to affiliated companies for insurance premiums that
were collected by the affiliated companies on behalf of insurance carriers, but
these amounts are not included in the totals referenced above, as the amounts
were paid over to insurance carriers for services provided by those carriers.
Although neither the Committee nor the Board expressly approved the other
services, the Committee determined that the consultant is independent because
(a) he was first engaged by the Committee before he became associated with
Mercer; (b) he works exclusively for the Committee and not for our management;
(c) he does not benefit from the other work that Mercer&#146;s parent and affiliated
companies perform for Kroger; and (d) neither the consultant nor the
consultant&#146;s team perform any other services on behalf of Kroger.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>B</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>OARD</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>
O</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>VERSIGHT</FONT></B> <B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>
OF</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2> E</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>NTERPRISE</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>
R</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>ISK</FONT></B></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>While risk management is primarily the responsibility of Kroger&#146;s
management team, the Board of Directors is responsible for the overall
supervision of our risk management activities. The Board&#146;s oversight of the
material risks faced by Kroger occurs at both the full Board level and at the
committee level. </FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>The Board&#146;s Audit Committee has oversight responsibility not only for
financial reporting of Kroger&#146;s major financial exposures and the steps
management has taken to monitor and control those exposures, but also for the
effectiveness of management&#146;s processes that monitor and manage key business
risks facing Kroger, as well as the major areas of risk exposure and
management&#146;s efforts to monitor and control that exposure. The Audit Committee
also discusses with management its policies with respect to risk assessment and
risk management.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>Management, including Kroger&#146;s Chief Ethics and Compliance Officer,
provides regular updates throughout the year to the respective committees
regarding the management of the risks they oversee, and each of these committees
reports on risk to the full Board at each regular meeting of the
Board.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>In addition to the reports from the committees, the Board receives
presentations throughout the year from various department and business unit
leaders that include discussion of significant risks as necessary. At each Board
meeting, the Chairman and CEO address matters of particular importance or
concern, including any significant areas of risk that require Board attention.
Additionally, through dedicated sessions focusing entirely on corporate
strategy, the full Board reviews in detail Kroger&#146;s short- and long-term
strategies, including consideration of significant risks facing Kroger and their
potential impact. The independent directors, in executive sessions led by the
Lead Director, address matters of particular concern, including significant
areas of risk, that warrant further discussion or consideration outside the
presence of Kroger employees.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>We believe that our approach to risk oversight, as described above,
optimizes our ability to assess inter-relationships among the various risks, make
informed cost-benefit decisions, and approach emerging risks in a proactive
manner for Kroger. We also believe that our risk structure complements our
current Board leadership structure, as it allows our independent directors,
through the five fully independent Board committees, and </FONT></P>
<P align=center><B><FONT face="Times New Roman">16</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>

<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>in executive sessions of independent
directors led by an independent Lead Director, to exercise effective oversight
of the actions of management, led by Mr. Dillon as Chairman and CEO, in
identifying risks and implementing effective risk management policies and
controls.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>B</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>OARD</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>
L</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>EADERSHIP</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2> S</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>TRUCTURE</FONT></B></P>
<P align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Our Board is
composed of twelve independent directors and two management directors, Mr.
Dillon, the Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer, and Mr. McMullen,
President and Chief Operating Officer. In addition, as provided in our
</FONT><I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Guidelines on Issues of Corporate
Governance</FONT></I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>, the Board has designated one of
the independent directors as Lead Director. The Board has established five
standing committees &#151; audit, compensation, corporate governance, financial
policy, and public responsibilities. Each of the Board committees is composed
solely of independent directors, each with a different independent director
serving as committee chair. We believe that the mix of experienced independent
and management directors that make up our Board, along with the independent role
of our Lead Director and our independent Board committees, benefits Kroger and
its shareholders.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>The Board believes that it is beneficial to Kroger and its shareholders
to designate one of the directors as a Lead Director. The Lead Director serves a
variety of roles, including reviewing and approving Board agendas, meeting
materials and schedules to confirm the appropriate topics are reviewed and
sufficient time is allocated to each; serving as liaison between the Chairman of
the Board, management, and the non-management directors; presiding at the
executive sessions of independent directors and at all other meetings of the
Board of Directors at which the Chairman of the Board is not present; and
calling an executive session of independent directors at any time. Bobby
Shackouls, an independent director and the chair of the Corporate Governance
Committee, is currently our Lead Director. Mr. Shackouls is an effective Lead
Director for Kroger due to, among other things, his independence, his deep
strategic and operational understanding of Kroger obtained while serving as a
Kroger director, his corporate governance knowledge acquired during his tenure
as a member of our Corporate Governance Committee, his previous experience on
other boards, and his prior experience as a CEO of a Fortune 500
company.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>With respect to the roles of Chairman and CEO, the </FONT><I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Guidelines</FONT></I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2> provide that the
Board believes that it is in the best interests of Kroger and its shareholders
for one person to serve as Chairman and CEO. The Board recognizes that there may
be circumstances in which it is in the best interests of Kroger and its
shareholders for the roles to be separated, and the Board exercises its
discretion as it deems appropriate in light of prevailing circumstances. The
Board believes that the combination or separation of these positions should
continue to be considered as part of the succession planning process, as was the
case in 2003 when the roles were separated. Since 2004, the roles have been
combined.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>Our Board and each of its committees conduct an annual evaluation to
determine whether they are functioning effectively. As part of this annual
self-evaluation, the Board assesses whether the current leadership structure
continues to be appropriate for Kroger and its shareholders. Our </FONT><I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Guidelines</FONT></I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2> provide the
flexibility for our Board to modify our leadership structure in the future as
appropriate. We believe that Kroger, like many U.S. companies, has been
well-served by this flexible leadership structure.</FONT></P>
<P align=center><B><FONT face="Times New Roman">17</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>

<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>
<TABLE style="LINE-HEIGHT: 14pt; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse" cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>

  <TR vAlign=bottom>
    <TD style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1pt solid; text-align: center" noWrap width="99%"><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>C</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>OMPENSATION </FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>D</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>ISCUSSION
      </FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>AND </FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>A</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>NALYSIS</FONT></B></TD></TR></TABLE><BR>
<P align=justify><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>E</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>XECUTIVE</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>
C</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>OMPENSATION</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2> O</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>VERVIEW</FONT></B></P>
<P align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>As the largest
traditional food and drug retailer in the United States, our executive
compensation philosophy is to attract and retain the best management talent and
to motivate these employees to achieve our business and financial goals. Our
strategy is designed to create value for shareholders in a manner consistent
with our focus on our core values: honesty, integrity, respect, inclusion,
diversity, and safety.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>To achieve our objectives, our Compensation Committee seeks to ensure
that compensation is competitive and that there is a direct link between pay and
performance, using the following guiding principles:</FONT></P>
<UL style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt"><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>A significant portion of pay should be
  performance-based, increasing proportionally with an executive&#146;s</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>level of responsibility;</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Compensation should include incentive-based pay to
  drive performance, providing superior pay for</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>superior performance, with both a short- and long-term focus;</FONT>
  <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Compensation policies should include an
  opportunity for and a requirement of equity ownership; and</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Components of compensation should be tied to an
  evaluation of business and individual performance</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>measured against metrics that align with our business strategy.</FONT>
  </LI></UL>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>Our 2011 fiscal year results compared against the compensation of senior
executives demonstrated these principles, and illustrated how our compensation
program responds to business challenges and the marketplace. While many
companies have struggled unsuccessfully during this difficult economy, we have
continued to deliver sales growth and positive earnings results.</FONT></P>
<UL style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt"><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Our identical supermarket sales, excluding fuel,
  increased 4.9% compared to 2010. This result was</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>substantially better than most of our competitors&#146; sales growth and
  exceeded our objectives.</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Our earnings per diluted share were $2.00,
  excluding the effect of the UFCW pension plan consolidation</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>charge. These results, during the challenging operating
  environment of 2011, also exceeded our</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>objectives.</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Annual cash dividends declared per common share
  during the year increased 10% over 2010.</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>As described below, short-term performance-based
  compensation, or annual cash bonus, of 138.666% of</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>bonus potentials paid to the named executive officers, exceeded both
  the average of 76% over the prior</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>nine years,
  and the 53.868% paid in 2010. This reflects the extent to which Kroger was
  able to exceed</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>increasingly more challenging
  targets for sales, earnings, our strategic plan, and our fuel program,
  as</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>well as year-over-year improvement from
  2010.</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Beginning in 2010, fifty percent of the time-based
  equity awards that otherwise would have been granted</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>to the named executive officers as restricted stock have been replaced
  with performance units that are</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>earned only to
  the extent that performance objectives are achieved.</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Equity compensation awards continued to play an
  important role in rewarding named executive officers</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>for the achievement of long-term business objectives and providing
  incentives for the creation of</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>shareholder
  value.</FONT> </LI></UL>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>In sum, the Committee believes our management produced outstanding
results in 2011, exceeding our aggressive business plan objectives for sales,
earnings, and our strategic plan. The compensation paid to our named executive
officers reflected this fact as the performance-based cash bonus paid out at
138.666% of bonus potentials. Further, the equity-based portion of compensation,
the value of which is tied to the return received by our shareholders in the
stock market, grew in value by 16% during 2011. This is shown in the performance
graph appearing at page A-3 of the accompanying annual report.</FONT></P>
<P align=center><B><FONT face="Times New Roman">18</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>

<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>
<P align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>In keeping
with our overall compensation philosophy, we endeavor to ensure that our
compensation practices conform to best practices when identified. In particular,
over the past several years we have:</FONT></P>
<UL style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt"><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>put in place significant stock ownership guideline
  levels to reinforce the link between the interests of</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>our named executive officers and those of our shareholders;</FONT>
<BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>adopted claw-back policies under which the
  repayment of bonuses may be required in certain</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>circumstances;</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>eliminated tax gross-ups; and</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>adopted the recommendation of shareholders that
  they be permitted annually, on an advisory basis, to</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>vote on executive compensation.</FONT> </LI></UL>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>The Compensation Committee of the Board has the primary responsibility
for establishing the compensation of Kroger&#146;s executive officers, including the
named executive officers, with the exception of the Chief Executive Officer. The
Committee&#146;s role regarding the CEO&#146;s compensation is to make recommendations to
the independent members of the Board; those independent Board members establish
the CEO&#146;s compensation.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>The following discussion and analysis addresses the compensation of the
named executive officers, and the factors considered by the Committee in setting
compensation for the named executive officers and making recommendations to the
independent Board members in the case of the CEO&#146;s compensation. Additional
detail is provided in the compensation tables and the accompanying narrative
disclosures that follow this discussion and analysis.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>E</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>XECUTIVE</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>
C</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>OMPENSATION&nbsp;&ndash;&nbsp;</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>O</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>BJECTIVES</FONT></B></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>The Committee has several related objectives regarding compensation.
First, the Committee believes that compensation must be designed to attract and
retain those best suited to fulfill the challenging roles that executive
officers play at Kroger. Second, some elements of compensation should help align
the interests of the officers with your interests as shareholders. Third,
compensation should create strong incentives for the officers (a) to achieve the
annual business plan targets established by the Board, and (b) to ensure that
the officers achieve Kroger&#146;s long-term strategic objectives. In developing
compensation programs and amounts to meet these objectives, the Committee
exercises judgment to ensure that executive officer compensation is appropriate
and competitive in light of Kroger&#146;s performance and the needs of the
business.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>To meet these objectives, the Committee has taken a number of steps over
the last several years, including the following:</FONT></P>
<UL style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; text-align: justify"><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Consulted regularly with its independent advisor
  from Mercer Human Resource Consulting on the design</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>of compensation plans and on the amount of compensation that is
  necessary and appropriate for Kroger&#146;s</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>senior
  leaders in light of the Committee&#146;s objectives. From time to time, and most
  recently in 2009, the</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Committee retains a
  second independent consultant to determine whether the compensation plans
  and</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>amounts comport with the Committee&#146;s
  objectives and produce value for Kroger&#146;s shareholders.</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Conducted an annual review of all components of
  compensation, quantifying total compensation for the</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>named executive officers on tally sheets. The review includes an
  assessment for each named executive</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>officer,
  including the CEO, of salary; performance-based cash compensation, or bonus
  (both annual and</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>long-term); equity;
  accumulated realized and unrealized stock option gains and restricted stock
  and</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>performance unit values; the value of any
  perquisites; retirement benefits; severance benefits available</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>under The Kroger Co. Employee Protection Plan; and earnings
  and payouts available under Kroger&#146;s</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>nonqualified deferred compensation program.</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Considered internal pay equity at Kroger. The
  Committee is aware of reported concerns at other</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>companies regarding disproportionate compensation awards to chief
  executive officers. The Committee</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>has assured
  itself that the compensation of Kroger&#146;s CEO and that of the other named
  executive officers</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>bears a reasonable
  relationship to the compensation levels of other executive positions at Kroger
  taking</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>into consideration performance and
  differences in responsibilities.</FONT> </LI></UL>
<P align=center><B><FONT face="Times New Roman">19</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>

<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>
<UL style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt"><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Recommended share ownership guidelines, adopted by
  the Board of Directors. These guidelines require</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>directors, officers and some other key executives to acquire and hold a
  minimum dollar value of Kroger</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>shares. The
  guidelines require the CEO to acquire and maintain ownership of Kroger shares
  equal to</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>5 times his base salary; the Chief
  Operating Officer at 4 times his base salary; Executive Vice
  Presidents,</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Senior Vice Presidents and
  non-employee directors at 3 times their base salaries or annual base
  cash</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>retainers; and other officers and key
  executives at 2 times their base salaries.</FONT> </LI></UL>
<P align=justify><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>R</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>ESULTS</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>
OF</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2> 2011 A</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>DVISORY</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>
V</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>OTE</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>
TO</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2> A</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>PPROVE</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>
E</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>XECUTIVE </FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>C</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>OMPENSATION</FONT></B></P>
<P align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>At the 2011
Annual Meeting of Shareholders, we held our first advisory vote on executive
compensation. Over 97% of the votes cast were in favor of this advisory
proposal. The Committee considered this favorable outcome and believed it
conveyed our shareholders&#146; support of the Committee&#146;s decisions and the existing
executive compensation programs. As a result, the Committee made no material
changes in the structure of our compensation programs or pay for performance
philosophy. At the 2012 Annual Meeting of Shareholders, as requested by the
shareholders, we will again hold an annual advisory vote to approve executive
compensation (see page 46). The Committee will continue to consider the results
from this year&#146;s and future advisory votes on executive compensation.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>E</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>STABLISHING</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>
E</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>XECUTIVE</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2> C</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>OMPENSATION</FONT></B></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>The independent members of the Board have the exclusive authority to
determine the amount of the CEO&#146;s salary; the bonus potential for the CEO; the
nature and amount of any equity awards made to the CEO; and any other
compensation questions related to the CEO. In setting the annual bonus potential
for the CEO, the independent directors determine the dollar amount that will be
multiplied by the percentage payout under the annual bonus plan generally
applicable to all corporate management, including the named executive officers.
The independent directors retain discretion to reduce the percentage payout the
CEO would otherwise receive. The independent directors thus make a separate
determination annually concerning both the CEO&#146;s bonus potential and the
percentage of bonus paid.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>The Committee performs the same function and exercises the same authority
as to the other named executive officers. The Committee&#146;s annual review of
compensation for the named executive officers includes the following:</FONT></P>
<UL style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt"><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>A detailed report, by officer, that describes
  current compensation, the value of equity compensation</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>previously awarded, the value of retirement benefits earned, and any
  severance or other benefits payable</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>upon a
  change of control.</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>An internal equity comparison of compensation at
  various senior levels. This current and historical</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>analysis is undertaken to ensure that the relationship of CEO
  compensation to other senior officer</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>compensation, and senior officer compensation to other levels in the
  organization, is equitable.</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>A report from the Committee&#146;s compensation
  consultants (described below) comparing named executive</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>officer and other senior executive compensation with that of
  other companies, primarily our competitors,</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>to
  ensure that the Committee&#146;s objectives of competitiveness are met.</FONT>
<BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>A recommendation from the CEO (except in the case
  of his own compensation) for salary, bonus</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>potential, and equity awards for each of the senior officers including
  the other named executive officers. The
  CEO&#146;s recommendation takes into consideration the objectives established by
  and the reports</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>received by the Committee as
  well as his assessment of individual job performance and contribution
  to</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>our management team.</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Historical information regarding salary, bonus and
  equity compensation for a 3-year period.</FONT> </LI></UL>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>In considering each of the factors above, the Committee does not make use
of a formula, but rather subjectively reviews each in making its compensation
determination.</FONT></P>
<P align=center><B><FONT face="Times New Roman">20</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>

<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>
<!--PART C-->
<P align=justify><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>T</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>HE</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2> C</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>OMMITTEE</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>&#146;</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>S</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2> C</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>OMPENSATION</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>
C</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>ONSULTANTS</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2> </FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>AND</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2> B</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>ENCHMARKING</FONT></B></P>
<P align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>As
referenced earlier in this proxy statement, the Committee directly engages a
compensation consultant from Mercer Human Resource Consulting to advise the
Committee in the design of compensation for executive officers.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT>The Mercer consultant conducts an
annual competitive assessment of executive positions at Kroger for the
Committee. The assessment is one of several bases, as described above, on which
the Committee determines compensation. The consultant assesses:</FONT></P>
<UL style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Base salary;</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Target annual performance-based bonus;</FONT>
  <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Target cash compensation (the sum of salary and
  bonus);</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Annualized long-term incentive awards, such as
  stock options, restricted shares, and performance-based</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>long-term cash bonuses and performance-based equity awards;
  and</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Total direct compensation (the sum of all these
  elements).</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>The consultant compares these elements against
  those of other companies in a group of publicly-traded</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>food and drug retailers. For 2011, the group consisted of:</FONT>
</LI></UL>
<TABLE style="LINE-HEIGHT: 14pt; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse" cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>

  <TR vAlign=bottom>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="20%"></TD>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="30%"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Costco Wholesale</FONT></TD>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="50%"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Supervalu</FONT></TD></TR>
  <TR vAlign=bottom>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="20%"></TD>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="30%"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>CVS/Caremark</FONT></TD>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="50%"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Target</FONT></TD></TR>
  <TR vAlign=bottom>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="20%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="30%"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Rite Aid</FONT></TD>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="50%"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Wal-Mart</FONT></TD></TR>
  <TR vAlign=bottom>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="20%"></TD>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="30%"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Safeway</FONT></TD>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="50%"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Walgreens</FONT></TD></TR></TABLE><BR>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>This peer group is the same group as
was used in 2010, with the exception that Great Atlantic &amp; Pacific Tea was
eliminated in 2011 due to its bankruptcy.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>The
make-up of the compensation peer group is reviewed annually and modified as
circumstances warrant. Industry consolidation and other competitive forces will
change the peer group used over time. The consultant also provides the Committee
data from companies in &#147;general industry,&#148; a representation of major
publicly-traded companies. These data are reference points, particularly for
senior staff positions where competition for talent extends beyond the retail
sector.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT>In 2009, the Committee directly
engaged an additional compensation consultant to conduct a review of Kroger&#146;s
executive compensation. This consultant, from Frederic W. Cook &amp; Co., Inc.,
examined the compensation philosophy, peer group composition, annual cash bonus,
and long-term incentive compensation including equity awards. The consultant
concluded that Kroger&#146;s executive compensation program met the Committee&#146;s
objectives, and that it provides a strong linkage between pay and performance.
The Committee expects to engage an additional compensation consultant from time
to time as it deems advisable.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT>Kroger is the second-largest company
as measured by annual revenues when compared with the peer group referenced
above and is the largest traditional food and drug retailer. The Committee has
therefore sought to ensure that salaries paid to our executive officers are at
or above the median paid by competitors for comparable positions and to provide
an annual bonus potential to our executive officers that, if annual business
plan objectives are achieved, would cause their total cash compensation to be
meaningfully above the median.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>C</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>OMPONENTS</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2> </FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>OF</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2> E</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>XECUTIVE</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>
C</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>OMPENSATION</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2> </FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>AT</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2> K</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>ROGER</FONT></B></P>
<P align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Compensation for our named executive officers is comprised of the
following:</FONT></P>
<UL style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Salary;</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Performance-Based Annual Cash Bonus (annual,
  non-equity incentive pay);</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Performance-Based Long-Term Cash Bonus (long-term,
  non-equity incentive pay);</FONT> </LI></UL>
<P align=center><B><FONT face="Times New Roman">21</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>

<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>
<UL style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Equity, including performance-based equity;</FONT>
  <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Retirement and other benefits; and</FONT>
  <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Perquisites.</FONT> </LI></UL>
<P align=justify><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>S</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>ALARY</FONT></B></P>
<P align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>We
provide our named executive officers and other employees a fixed amount of cash
compensation &#150; salary &#150; for their work. Salaries for named executive officers
(with the exception of the CEO) are established each year by the Committee. The
CEO&#146;s salary is established by the independent directors. Salaries for the named
executive officers were reviewed in June.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT>The amount of each executive&#146;s
salary is influenced by numerous factors including:</FONT></P>
<UL style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>An assessment of individual contribution in the
  judgment of the CEO and the Committee (or, in the case</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>of the CEO, of the Committee and the rest of the independent
  directors);</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Benchmarking with comparable positions at peer
  group companies;</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Tenure; and</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Relationship with the salaries of other executives
  at Kroger.</FONT> </LI></UL>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT>The assessment of individual
contribution is based on a subjective determination, without the use of
performance targets, in the following areas:</FONT></P>
<UL style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Leadership;</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Contribution to the officer group;</FONT>
  <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Achievement of established objectives, to the
  extent applicable;</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Decision-making abilities;</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Performance of the areas or groups directly
  reporting to the officer;</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Increased responsibilities;</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Strategic thinking; and</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Furtherance of Kroger&#146;s core values.</FONT>
</LI></UL>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT>The amounts shown below reflect the
salaries of the named executive officers in effect following the annual review
of their compensation in June of each year.</FONT></P>

<P align=center><B><FONT face="Times New Roman">22</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>

<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>
<P align=justify><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>P</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>ERFORMANCE</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>-B</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>ASED </FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>A</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>NNUAL</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2> C</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>ASH</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2> B</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>ONUS</FONT></B></P>
<P align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>A large
percentage of our employees at all levels, including the named executive
officers, are eligible to receive a performance-based annual cash bonus based on
Kroger or unit performance. The Committee establishes bonus potentials for each
executive officer, other than the CEO whose bonus potential is established by
the independent directors. Actual payouts, which can exceed 100% of the
potential amounts, represent the extent to which performance meets or exceeds
the thresholds established by the Committee.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT>The Committee considers several
factors in making its determination or recommendation as to bonus potentials.
First, the individual&#146;s level within the organization is a factor in that the
Committee believes that more senior executives should have a substantial part of
their compensation dependent upon Kroger&#146;s performance. Second, the individual&#146;s
salary is a factor so that a substantial portion of a named executive officer&#146;s
total cash compensation is dependent upon Kroger&#146;s performance. Finally, the
Committee considers the reports of its compensation consultants to assess the
bonus potential of the named executive officers in light of total compensation
paid to comparable executive positions in the industry.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT>The annual cash bonus potential in
effect at the end of the year for each named executive officer is shown below.
Actual bonus payouts are prorated to reflect changes, if any, to bonus
potentials during the year.</FONT></P>
<TABLE style="LINE-HEIGHT: 14pt; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse" cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>

  <TR vAlign=bottom>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="82%"></TD>
    <TD noWrap style="text-align: center" width="1%"></TD>
    <TD style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1pt solid; text-align: center" noWrap width="17%" colSpan=8><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>Annual Bonus Potential</FONT></B></TD></TR>
  <TR vAlign=bottom>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="82%"></TD>
    <TD noWrap style="text-align: center" width="1%" bgColor=#ffffff>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1pt solid; text-align: center" noWrap width="5%" colSpan=2><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>2009</FONT></B></TD>
    <TD noWrap style="text-align: center" width="1%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1pt solid; text-align: center" noWrap width="5%" colSpan=2><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>2010</FONT></B></TD>
    <TD noWrap style="text-align: center" width="1%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1pt solid; text-align: center" noWrap width="5%" colSpan=2><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>2011</FONT></B></TD></TR>
  <TR vAlign=bottom>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="82%" bgColor=#c0c0c0><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>David B. Dillon</FONT></TD>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="1%" bgColor=#c0c0c0></TD>

<TABLE style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify" cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 border=0>

  <TR>
    <TD vAlign=top noWrap><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>*</FONT></TD>
    <TD vAlign=top noWrap><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="100%"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Mr. Donnelly became a named
      executive officer in 2011.</FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT>The amount of bonus that the named
executive officers earn each year is determined by Kroger&#146;s performance compared
to targets established by the Committee based on the business plan adopted by
the Board of Directors. In 2011, thirty percent of bonus was earned based on an
identical sales target for Kroger&#146;s supermarkets and other business operations;
thirty percent was based on a target for EBITDA, excluding supermarket fuel; and
forty percent was based on implementation and results of a set of measures under
our strategic plan. An additional 5% would be earned if Kroger achieved three
goals with respect to its supermarket fuel operations; achievement of the
targeted fuel EBITDA as set forth in the business plan, increase of at least 3%
in gallons sold at identical fuel centers, and achievement of the planned number
of fuel centers placed in service.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT>Over time the Committee has placed
an increased emphasis on the strategic plan by making the target more difficult
to achieve. The bonus plan allows for minimal bonus to be earned at relatively
low levels to provide incentive for achieving even higher levels of
performance.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT>Following the close of the year, the
Committee reviewed Kroger&#146;s performance against the identical sales, EBITDA, and
strategic plan objectives and determined the extent to which Kroger achieved
those objectives. Kroger&#146;s EBITDA for 2011 was $3.899 billion, and Kroger&#146;s
identical retail sales for 2011, excluding supermarket fuel, were 4.9%. In
2011, Kroger&#146;s supermarket fuel EBITDA was $183.210 million, which exceeded the
goal of $122.865 million necessary to earn a bonus for the fuel component.
Kroger&#146;s sale of fuel in identical supermarket fuel centers was 3.371 billion
gallons, or 2.6% over the prior year. We operated 1,090 supermarket fuel centers
as of the end of 2011, exceeding our goal of 1,075 centers. As a result, the
officers earned the additional 5% fuel bonus. Due to the Company&#146;s excellent
performance when compared to the targets established by the Committee, and based
on the business plan adopted by the Board of Directors, the named executive
officers earned 138.666% of their bonus potentials, which percentage payout
exceeded that of last year and the average bonus payout over the previous
several years. This reflects Kroger&#146;s outstanding performance in exceeding its
aggressive EBITDA, sales, and strategic plan goals.</FONT></P>
<P align=center><B><FONT face="Times New Roman">23</FONT></B></P>

<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT>In 2011, as in all years, the
Committee retained discretion to reduce the bonus payout for all executive
officers, including the named executive officers, if the Committee determined
for any reason that the bonus payouts were not appropriate. The independent
directors retained that discretion for the CEO&#146;s bonus. Those bodies also
retained discretion to adjust the targets under the plan should unanticipated
developments arise during the year. No adjustments were made to the targets. The
Committee, and the independent directors in the case of the CEO, determined that
the bonus payouts for the named executive officers should remain the same as
other participants.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT>The percentage paid for 2011
represented and resulted from performance that significantly exceeded our
business plan objectives. A comparison of bonus percentages for the named
executive officers in prior years demonstrates the variability of incentive
compensation:</FONT></P>
