    <TD noWrap align=right width="1%"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>$</FONT></TD>
    <TD noWrap align=right width="3%"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>25/($25)</FONT></TD>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="1%"></TD></TR></TABLE><BR>
<P align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>We contributed
$52 million in 2011, $141 million in 2010 and $265 million in 2009 to our
Company-sponsored defined benefit pension plans. Although we are not required to
make cash contributions to our Company-sponsored defined benefit pension plans
during 2012, we expect to contribute approximately $75 million to these plans in
2012. Additional contributions may be made if required under the Pension
Protection Act to avoid any benefit restrictions. We expect any contributions
made during 2012 will decrease our required contributions in future years. Among
other things, investment performance of plan assets, the interest rates required
to be used to calculate the pension obligations, and future changes in
legislation, will determine the amounts of any contributions.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>We contributed and expensed $130 million in 2011, $119 million in 2010
and $115 million in 2009 to employee 401(k) retirement savings accounts. The
401(k) retirement savings account plans provide to eligible employees both
matching contributions and automatic contributions from the Company based on
participant contributions, plan compensation, and length of service.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><EM>Multi-Employer Pension Plans</EM></FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>We also contribute to various multi-employer pension plans based on
obligations arising from collective bargaining agreements. These plans provide
retirement benefits to participants based on their service to contributing
employers. The benefits are paid from assets held in trust for that purpose.
Trustees are appointed in equal number by employers and unions. The trustees
typically are responsible for determining the level of benefits to be provided
to participants as well as for such matters as the investment of the assets and
the administration of the plans.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>In the fourth quarter of 2011, we entered into a memorandum of
understanding (&#147;MOU&#148;) with 14 locals of the UFCW that participated in four
multi-employer pension funds. The MOU established a process that amended each of
the collective bargaining agreements between Kroger and the UFCW locals under
which we made contributions to these funds and consolidated the four
multi-employer pension funds into one multi-employer pension fund.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Under the
terms of the MOU, the locals of the UFCW agreed to a future pension benefit
formula through 2021. We were designated as the named fiduciary of the new
consolidated plan with sole investment authority over its assets. We committed
to contribute sufficient funds to cover the actuarial cost of current accruals
and to fund the pre-consolidation Unfunded Actuarial Accrued Liability (&#147;UAAL&#148;)
that existed as of December 31, 2011, in a series of installments on or before
March 31, 2018. At January 1, 2012, the UAAL was estimated to be $911 million
(pre-tax). In accordance with GAAP, we expensed $911 million in 2011 related to
the UAAL. The expense was based on a preliminary estimate of the contractual
commitment. As the estimate is updated, we may incur additional expense. We do
not expect any adjustments to be material. In the fourth quarter of 2011, we
contributed $650 million to the consolidated multi-employer pension plan of
which $600 million was allocated to the UAAL and $50 million was allocated to
service and interest costs and expensed in 2011. Future contributions will be
dependent, among other things, on the investment performance of assets in the
plan. The funding commitments under the MOU replace the prior commitments under
the four existing funds to pay an agreed upon amount per hour worked by eligible
employees.</FONT></P>
<P align=center><B><FONT face="Times New Roman">A-15</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>

<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>
<P align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>We recognize
expense in connection with these plans as contributions are funded or, in the
case of the UFCW consolidated pension plan, when commitments are made, in
accordance with GAAP. We made cash contributions to these plans of $946 million
in 2011, $262 million in 2010 and $233 million in 2009. The cash contributions
for 2011 include the Company&#146;s $650 million contribution to the UFCW
consolidated pension plan in the fourth quarter of 2011.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>Based on the most recent information available to us, we believe that the
present value of actuarially accrued liabilities in most of these multi-employer
plans substantially exceeds the value of the assets held in trust to pay
benefits. We have attempted to estimate the amount by which these liabilities
exceed the assets, (i.e., the amount of underfunding), as of December 31, 2011.
Because Kroger is only one of a number of employers contributing to these plans,
we also have attempted to estimate the ratio of Kroger&#146;s contributions to the
total of all contributions to these plans in a year as a way of assessing
Kroger&#146;s &#147;share&#148; of the underfunding. Nonetheless, the underfunding is not a
direct obligation or liability of Kroger or of any employer except as noted
above. As of December 31, 2011, we estimate that Kroger&#146;s share of the
underfunding of multi-employer plans to which Kroger contributes was $2.3
billion, pre-tax, or $1.4 billion, after-tax. This represents a decrease in the
estimated amount of underfunding of approximately $280 million, pre-tax, or $175
million, after-tax, as of December 31, 2011, compared to December 31, 2010. The
December 31, 2011 estimate of our underfunding includes the effect of our $650
million contribution to the UFCW consolidated pension plan made in January 2012.
The decrease in the amount of underfunding is attributable to the Company&#146;s $650
million contribution to the UFCW consolidated pension plan, partially offset by
increases in underfunded amounts in other plans. Our estimate is based on the
most current information available to us including actuarial evaluations and
other data (that include the estimates of others), and such information may be
outdated or otherwise unreliable.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>We have made and disclosed this estimate not because, except as noted
above, this underfunding is a direct liability of Kroger. Rather, we believe the
underfunding is likely to have important consequences. In 2011, excluding the
$650 million contribution to our UFCW consolidated pension plan, our
contributions to these plans increased approximately 13% over the prior year and
have grown at a compound annual rate of approximately 9% since 2006.
</FONT><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>In 2012, we expect to contribute approximately
$240 million to our multi-employer pension plans, subject to collective
bargaining and capital market conditions. This amount reflects a contribution
decrease due to the UFCW consolidated pension plan. Based on current market
conditions, we expect meaningful increases in funding and in expense as a result
of increases in multi-employer pension plan contributions over the next few
years</FONT><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>. Finally, underfunding means that, in the
event we were to exit certain markets or otherwise cease making contributions to
these funds, we could trigger a substantial withdrawal liability. Any adjustment
for withdrawal liability will be recorded when it is probable that a liability
exists and can be reasonably estimated, in accordance with GAAP.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>The amount of underfunding described above is an estimate and could
change based on contract negotiations, returns on the assets held in the
multi-employer plans and benefit payments. The amount could decline, and
Kroger&#146;s future expense would be favorably affected, if the values of the assets
held in the trust significantly increase or if further changes occur through
collective bargaining, trustee action or favorable legislation. On the other
hand, Kroger&#146;s share of the underfunding could increase and Kroger&#146;s future
expense could be adversely affected if the asset values decline, if employers
currently contributing to these funds cease participation or if changes occur
through collective bargaining, trustee action or adverse legislation.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>See Note 14 to the Consolidated Financial Statements for more information
relating to our participation in these multi-employer pension plans.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><EM>Deferred Rent</EM></FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>We recognize rent holidays, including the time period during which we
have access to the property for construction of buildings or improvements, as
well as construction allowances and escalating rent provisions on a
straight-line basis over the term of the lease. The deferred amount is included
in Other Current Liabilities and Other Long-Term Liabilities on the Consolidated
Balance Sheets.</FONT></P>
<P align=center><B><FONT face="Times New Roman">A-16</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>

<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><EM>Uncertain Tax Positions</EM></FONT></P>
<P align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>We review the
tax positions taken or expected to be taken on tax returns to determine whether
and to what extent a benefit can be recognized in our consolidated financial
statements. Refer to Note 4 to the Consolidated Financial Statements for the
amount of unrecognized tax benefits and other related disclosures related to
uncertain tax positions.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>Various taxing authorities periodically audit our income tax returns.
These audits include questions regarding our tax filing positions, including the
timing and amount of deductions and the allocation of income to various tax
jurisdictions. In evaluating the exposures connected with these various tax
filing positions, including state and local taxes, we record allowances for
probable exposures. A number of years may elapse before a particular matter, for
which an allowance has been established, is audited and fully resolved. As of
January 28, 2012, the most recent examination concluded by the Internal Revenue
Service covered the years 2005 through 2007.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>The assessment of our tax position relies on the judgment of management
to estimate the exposures associated with our various filing
positions.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><EM>Share-Based Compensation
Expense</EM></FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>We account for stock options under the fair value recognition provisions
of GAAP. Under this method, we recognize compensation expense for all
share-based payments granted. We recognize share-based compensation expense, net
of an estimated forfeiture rate, over the requisite service period of the award.
In addition, we record expense for restricted stock awards in an amount equal to
the fair market value of the underlying stock on the grant date of the award,
over the period the award restrictions lapse.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><EM>Inventories</EM></FONT></P>
<P align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Inventories
are stated at the lower of cost (principally on a LIFO basis) or market. In
total, approximately 97% of inventories were valued using the LIFO method in
both 2011 and 2010. Cost for the balance of the inventories was determined using
the FIFO method. Replacement cost was higher than the carrying amount by $1.0
billion at January 28, 2012, and by $827 million at January 29, 2011. We follow
the Link-Chain, Dollar-Value LIFO method for purposes of calculating our LIFO
charge or credit.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>We follow the item-cost method of accounting to determine inventory cost
before the LIFO adjustment for substantially all store inventories at our
supermarket divisions. This method involves counting each item in inventory,
assigning costs to each of these items based on the actual purchase costs (net
of vendor allowances and cash discounts) of each item and recording the cost of
items sold. The item-cost method of accounting allows for more accurate
reporting of periodic inventory balances and enables management to more
precisely manage inventory and purchasing levels when compared to the
methodology followed under the retail method of accounting.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>We evaluate inventory shortages throughout the year based on actual
physical counts in our facilities. We record allowances for inventory shortages
based on the results of recent physical counts to provide for estimated
shortages from the last physical count to the financial statement
date.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><EM>Vendor Allowances</EM></FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>We recognize all vendor allowances as a reduction in merchandise costs
when the related product is sold. In most cases, vendor allowances are applied
to the related product cost by item, and therefore reduce the carrying value of
inventory by item. When it is not practicable to allocate vendor allowances to
the product by item, we recognize vendor allowances as a reduction in
merchandise costs based on inventory turns and as the product is sold. We
recognized approximately $5.9 billion in 2011, $6.4 billion in 2010 and $5.7
billion in 2009 of vendor allowances as a reduction in merchandise costs. We
recognized approximately95% of all vendor allowances in the item cost with the
remainder being based on inventory turns.</FONT></P>
<P align=center><B><FONT face="Times New Roman">A-17</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>

<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>
<P align=justify><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>L</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>IQUIDITY</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2> </FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>AND</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2> C</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>APITAL</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>
R</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>ESOURCES</FONT></B></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><EM>Cash Flow Information</EM></FONT></P>
<P align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><U>Net cash
provided by operating activities</U></FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>We generated $2.7 billion of cash from operations in 2011, compared to
$3.4 billion in 2010 and $2.9 billion in 2009. The cash provided by operating
activities came from net earnings including noncontrolling interests adjusted
primarily for non-cash expenses of depreciation and amortization, the LIFO
charge, the goodwill impairment charge, and changes in working capital. The
decrease in net cash provided by operating activities in 2011, compared to 2010,
was primarily due to the decline in net earnings including noncontrolling
interests due to the UFCW consolidated pension plan charge. Changes in working
capital also provided (used) cash from operating activities of ($300) million in
2011, compared to $698 million in 2010 and ($83) million in 2009. The decrease
in cash provided by changes in working capital for 2011, compared to 2010, was
primarily due to an increase in inventories, offset partially by increases in
trade accounts payable and accrued expenses. In addition, the decrease in net
cash provided by operating activities in 2011, compared to 2010, was partially
offset by an increase in other long-term liabilities for our remaining estimated
commitment for the UAAL in excess of the cash contribution. The change in
working capital for 2010, compared to 2009, was primarily due to increases in
trade accounts payable and accrued expenses and a decrease in prepaid expenses.
In addition, the increase in net cash provided by operating activities in 2010,
compared to 2009, was partially offset by a decrease in other long-term
liabilities. Prepaid expenses decreased in 2010, compared to 2009, due to Kroger
not prefunding $300 million of employee benefits in 2010. These amounts are also
net of cash contributions to our Company-sponsored defined benefit pension plans
totaling $52 million in 2011, $141 million in 2010, and $265 million in 2009.
</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>The amount of cash paid for income taxes decreased in 2011, compared to
2010, primarily due to the decrease in net earnings including noncontrolling
interests and from the bonus depreciation deductions allowed by the 2010 Tax
Relief Act for property placed into service in 2011. The amount of cash paid for
income taxes increased in 2010, compared to 2009, due to reversals of temporary
differences in 2010 and overpayments being applied to 2009 income taxes.
</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT><U>Net cash used by investing activities</U></FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>Cash used by investing activities was $1.9 billion in 2011, compared to
$2.0 billion in 2010 and $2.3 billion in 2009. The amount of cash used by
investing activities decreased in 2011, compared to 2010, due to decreased
payments for other investing activities, offset partially by increased payments
for acquisitions. The amount of cash used by investing activities decreased in
2010, compared to 2009, due primarily to decreased payments on capital
expenditures. Capital expenditures, including changes in
construction-in-progress payables and excluding acquisitions, were $1.9 billion
in 2011, $1.9 billion in 2010, and $2.3 billion in 2009. Refer to the Capital
Expenditures section for an overview of our supermarket storing activity during
the last three years.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT><U>Net cash used by financing activities</U></FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>Financing activities used $1.4 billion of cash in 2011, compared to $1.0
billion in 2010 and $434 million in 2009. The increase in the amount of cash
used for financing activities in 2011, compared to 2010, was primarily related
to the increased payments for treasury stock purchases, partially offset by
increased borrowings under our commercial paper program. The increase in the
amount of cash used for financing activities in 2010, compared to 2009, was
primarily related to the increased payments on long-term debt and treasury stock
repurchases, decreased proceeds from the issuance of long-term debt, and an
investment in the remaining interest of a variable interest entity, partially
offset by decreased payments on the credit facility. We repurchased $1.5 billion
of Kroger common shares in 2011, compared to $545 million in 2010 and $218
million in 2009. We paid dividends totaling $257 million in 2011, $250 million
in 2010 and $238 million in 2009. </FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><EM>Debt Management</EM></FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>Total debt, including both the current and long-term portions of capital
leases and lease-financing obligations, increased $273 million to $8.2 billion
as of year-end 2011, compared to year-end 2010. The increase in 2011, compared
to 2010, resulted from increased net borrowings of commercial paper of $370
million and </FONT></P>
<P align=center><B><FONT face="Times New Roman">A-18</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>

<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>the issuance of $450 million of senior
notes bearing an interest rate of 2.20%, offset by the payment at maturity of
our $478 million of senior notes bearing an interest rate of 6.80%. Total debt
decreased $164 million to $7.9 billion as of year-end 2010, compared to year-end
2009. The decrease in 2010, compared to 2009, resulted from the payment at
maturity of our $500 million of senior notes bearing an interest rate of 8.05%,
offset by the issuance of $300 million of senior notes bearing an interest rate
of 5.40%. As of January 28, 2012, our cash and temporary cash investments were
$188 million compared to $825 million as of January 29, 2011. This decrease was
primarily due to the payment at maturity of our $478 million of senior notes,
our $650 million UFCW consolidated pension plan contribution and the increased
share repurchase activity noted above, partially offset by the borrowing of
commercial paper and the issuance of our $450 million of senior notes described
above.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Our total debt
balances were also affected by our prefunding of employee benefit costs and by
the mark-to-market adjustments necessary to record fair value interest rate
hedges on our fixed rate debt. In 2009, we prefunded employee benefit costs of
$300 million. The mark-to-market adjustments increased the carrying value of our
debt by $24 million in 2011 and $57 million in both 2010 and 2009.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><EM>Liquidity Needs</EM></FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>We estimate our liquidity needs over the next twelve month period to be
approximately $3.6 billion, which includes anticipated requirements for working
capital, capital expenditures, interest payments, and scheduled principal
payments of debt, offset by cash and temporary cash investments on hand at the
end of fiscal year 2011. Based on current operating trends, we believe that cash
flows from operating activities and other sources of liquidity, including
borrowings under our commercial paper program and bank credit facility, will be
adequate to meet our liquidity needs for the next twelve months and for the
foreseeable future beyond the next twelve months. We have approximately $1.3
billion of debt due in the next twelve months, which is included in the $3.6
billion in estimated liquidity needs. We expect to refinance this debt on
favorable terms based on our past experience. If necessary, we believe we can
also fund future scheduled principal payments of long-term debt from our cash
flows from operating activities. We also currently do not expect to purchase our
common shares at the levels we did in 2011. We used our commercial paper program
toward the end of 2011 to fund our common share purchases. We expect our
contributions to the UFCW consolidated pension plan to significantly decrease in
future periods. We may use our commercial paper program to fund debt maturities
in 2012 but do not expect to use the program permanently. We believe we have
adequate coverage of our debt covenants to continue to maintain our current debt
ratings and to respond effectively to competitive conditions.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><EM>Factors Affecting Liquidity</EM></FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>We can currently borrow on a daily basis approximately $1 billion under
our commercial paper (&#147;CP&#148;) program. At January 28, 2012, we had $370 million of
CP borrowings outstanding. CP borrowings are backed by our credit facility, and
reduce the amount we can borrow under the credit facility. If our short-term
credit ratings fall, the ability to borrow under our current CP program could be
adversely affected for a period of time and increase our interest cost on daily
borrowings under our CP program. This could require us to borrow additional
funds under the credit facility, under which we believe we have sufficient
capacity. However, in the event of a ratings decline, we do not anticipate that
our borrowing capacity under our CP program would be any lower than $500 million
on a daily basis. Although our ability to borrow under the credit facility is
not affected by our credit rating, the interest cost on borrowings under the
credit facility could be affected by an increase in our Leverage
Ratio.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>Our credit facility requires the maintenance of a Leverage Ratio and a
Fixed Charge Coverage Ratio (our &#147;financial covenants&#148;). A failure to maintain
our financial covenants would impair our ability to borrow under the credit
facility. These financial covenants and ratios are described below:</FONT></P>
<UL style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; text-align: justify">
<LI><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Our Leverage Ratio (the ratio of Net Debt to
  Consolidated EBITDA, as defined in the credit facility) was</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>1.85 to 1 as of January 28, 2012. If this ratio were to
  exceed 3.50 to 1, we would be in default of our</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>credit facility and our ability to borrow under the facility would be
  impaired. In addition, our Applicable</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Margin on
  borrowings is determined by our Leverage Ratio.</FONT> </LI></UL>
<P align=center><B><FONT face="Times New Roman">A-19</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>


<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV>
<!--PART C-->
<BR>
<UL style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt"><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Our Fixed Charge Coverage Ratio (the ratio of
  Consolidated EBITDA plus Consolidated Rental Expense to</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Consolidated Cash Interest Expense plus Consolidated Rental
  Expense, as defined in the credit facility)</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>was
  4.42 to 1 as of January 28, 2012. If this ratio fell below 1.70 to 1, we would
  be in default of our credit</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>facility and our
  ability to borrow under the facility would be impaired.</FONT> </LI></UL>
<P align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Consolidated
EBITDA, as defined in our credit facility, includes an adjustment for unusual
gains and losses including our UFCW consolidated pension plan charge in 2011.
Our credit agreement is more fully described in Note 5 to the Consolidated
Financial Statements. We were in compliance with our financial covenants at
year-end 2011.</FONT></P>

<P align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Our
construction commitments include funds owed to third parties for projects
currently under construction. These amounts are reflected in other current
liabilities in our Consolidated Balance Sheets.</FONT></P>
<P align=center><B><FONT face="Times New Roman">A-20</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>

<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>
<P align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Our purchase
obligations include commitments to be utilized in the normal course of business,
such as several contracts to purchase raw materials utilized in our
manufacturing plants and several contracts to purchase energy to be used in our
stores and manufacturing facilities. Our obligations also include management
fees for facilities operated by third parties. Any upfront vendor allowances or
incentives associated with outstanding purchase commitments are recorded as
either current or long-term liabilities in our Consolidated Balance
Sheets.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>As of January 28, 2012, we maintained a $2 billion (with the ability to
increase by $500 million), unsecured revolving credit facility that, unless
extended, terminates on January 25, 2017. We amended the credit agreement
subsequent to year-end 2011 to update our covenants for the exclusion of the
UFCW consolidated pension plan charge. All other terms remained the same.
Outstanding borrowings under the credit agreement and commercial paper
borrowings, and some outstanding letters of credit, reduce funds available under
the credit agreement. In addition to the credit agreement, we maintained two
uncommitted money market lines totaling $75 million in the aggregate. The money
market lines allow us to borrow from banks at mutually agreed upon rates,
usually at rates below the rates offered under the credit agreement. As of
January 28, 2012, we had $370 million of borrowings of commercial paper and no
borrowings under our credit agreement and money market lines. The outstanding
letters of credit that reduce funds available under our credit agreement totaled
$19 million as of January 28, 2012.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>In addition to the available credit mentioned above, as of January 28,
2012, we had authorized for issuance $1.6 billion of securities under a shelf
registration statement filed with the SEC and effective on December 15,
2010.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>We also maintain surety bonds related primarily to our self-insured
workers&#146; compensation claims. These bonds are required by most states in which
we are self-insured for workers&#146; compensation and are placed with third-party
insurance providers to insure payment of our obligations in the event we are
unable to meet our claim payment obligations up to our self-insured retention
levels. These bonds do not represent liabilities of Kroger, as we already have
reserves on our books for the claims costs. Market changes may make the surety
bonds more costly and, in some instances, availability of these bonds may become
more limited, which could affect our costs of, or access to, such bonds.
Although we do not believe increased costs or decreased availability would
significantly affect our ability to access these surety bonds, if this does
become an issue, we would issue letters of credit, in states where allowed,
against our credit facility to meet the state bonding requirements. This could
increase our cost and decrease the funds available under our credit
facility.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>We have guaranteed half of the indebtedness of two real estate entities
in which we have a 50% ownership interest. Our share of the responsibility for
this indebtedness, should the entities be unable to meet their obligations,
totals approximately $6 million. Based on the covenants underlying this
indebtedness as of January 28, 2012, we believe that it is unlikely that we will
be responsible for repayment of these obligations.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>We also are contingently liable for leases that have been assigned to
various third parties in connection with facility closings and dispositions. We
could be required to satisfy obligations under the leases if any of the
assignees are unable to fulfill their lease obligations. Due to the wide
distribution of our assignments among third parties, and various other remedies
available to us, we believe the likelihood that we will be required to assume a
material amount of these obligations is remote. We have agreed to indemnify
certain third-party logistics operators for certain expenses, including pension
trust fund contribution obligations and withdrawal liabilities.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>In addition to the above, we enter into various indemnification
agreements and take on indemnification obligations in the ordinary course of
business. Such arrangements include indemnities against third party claims
arising out of agreements to provide services to Kroger; indemnities related to
the sale of our securities; indemnities of directors, officers and employees in
connection with the performance of their work; and indemnities of individuals
serving as fiduciaries on benefit plans. While Kroger&#146;s aggregate
indemnification obligation could result in a material liability, we are not
aware of any current matter that could result in a material
liability.</FONT></P>
<P align=center><B><FONT face="Times New Roman">A-21</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>

<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>
<P align=justify><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>R</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>ECENTLY</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2> I</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>SSUED</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>
A</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>CCOUNTING</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2> S</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>TANDARDS</FONT></B></P>
<P align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>In September
2011, the FASB amended its standards related to the testing of goodwill for
impairment. The objective of this amendment is to simplify the annual goodwill
impairment evaluation process. The amendment provides entities the option to
first assess qualitative factors to determine whether it is more likely than not
that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying value as a
basis for determining whether it is necessary to perform the two-step goodwill
impairment test. The two-step impairment test is now only required if an entity
determines through this qualitative analysis that it is more likely than not
that the fair value of the reporting unit is less than its carrying value. The
new rules are effective for interim and annual periods beginning after December
15, 2011; however, entities were permitted to adopt the standards early. We did
not adopt these standards early for our 2011 goodwill impairment testing
process. Because the measurement of a potential impairment loss has not changed,
the amended standards will not have an effect on our Consolidated Financial
Statements.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>In June 2011, the FASB amended its rules regarding the presentation of
comprehensive income. The objective of this amendment is to improve the
comparability, consistency and transparency of financial reporting and to
increase the prominence of items reported in other comprehensive income.
Specifically, this amendment requires that all non-owner changes in
shareholders&#146; equity be presented either in a single continuous statement of
comprehensive income or in two separate but consecutive statements. The new
rules were to become effective for interim and annual periods beginning after
December 15, 2011. In December 2011, the FASB deferred certain aspects of this
standard beyond the December 15, 2011 effective date, specifically the
provisions dealing with reclassification adjustments. Because the standards only
affect the display of comprehensive income and do not affect what is included in
comprehensive income, the standards will not have a material effect on our
Consolidated Financial Statements.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>In May 2011, the FASB amended its standards related to fair value
measurements and disclosures. The objective of the amendment is to improve the
comparability of fair value measurements presented and disclosed in financial
statements prepared in accordance with GAAP and International Financial
Reporting Standards. This amendment primarily changed the wording used to
describe many of the requirements in GAAP for measuring fair value and for
disclosing information about fair value measurements. In addition, the amendment
clarified the FASB&#146;s intent about the application of existing fair value
measurement requirements. The new standard also requires additional disclosures
related to fair value measurements categorized within Level 3 of the fair value
hierarchy and requires disclosure of the categorization in the hierarchy for
items that are not recorded at fair value but as to which fair value is required
to be disclosed. The new rules became effective for interim and annual periods
beginning after December 15, 2011. While we are still finalizing our evaluation
of the effect of this amended standard on our Consolidated Financial Statements,
we believe this new standard will not have a material effect on our Consolidated
Financial Statements.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>O</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>UTLOOK</FONT></B></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>This discussion and analysis contains certain forward-looking statements
about Kroger&#146;s future performance. These statements are based on management&#146;s
assumptions and beliefs in light of the information currently available. Such
statements relate to, among other things: projected changes in net earnings
attributable to The Kroger Co.; identical supermarket sales growth; expected
product cost; expected pension plan contributions; our ability to generate
operating cash flows; projected capital expenditures; square footage growth;
opportunities to reduce costs; cash flow requirements; and our operating plan
for the future; and are indicated by words such as &#147;comfortable,&#148; &#147;committed,&#148;
&#147;will,&#148; &#147;expect,&#148; &#147;goal,&#148; &#147;should,&#148; &#147;intend,&#148; &#147;target,&#148; &#147;believe,&#148; &#147;anticipate,&#148;
&#147;plan,&#148; and similar words or phrases. These forward-looking statements are
subject to uncertainties and other factors that could cause actual results to
differ materially.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>Statements elsewhere in this report and below regarding our expectations,
projections, beliefs, intentions or strategies are forward-looking statements
within the meaning of Section 21E of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. While
we believe that the statements are accurate, uncertainties about the general
economy, our labor relations, our ability to execute our plans on a timely basis
and other uncertainties described below could cause actual results to differ
materially.</FONT></P>
<P align=center><B><FONT face="Times New Roman">A-22</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>

<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>
<UL style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt"><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>We expect net earnings per diluted share in the
  range of $2.28-$2.38 for 2012. This guidance assumes the</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>benefit of the 53<SUP>rd </SUP>week, a lower expected LIFO
  charge, the benefit of our share buyback program during</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>2011, the benefit from the pension plan consolidation and
  the benefit from transfers of prescriptions to</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>our stores from customers that previously used a former third party
  pharmacy provider to obtain their</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Express
  Scripts benefits.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>We expect identical supermarket sales growth,
  excluding fuel sales, of 3.0%-3.5% in 2012. This guidance</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>contemplates the effect of several brand prescription drugs
  coming off patent during 2012, which will</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>reduce sales because generic equivalents have a lower retail
  price.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Our business model is designed to produce annual
  earnings per diluted share growth on average of</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>6.0% to 8.0% over a rolling three to five year time horizon. Including
  our dividend, our business model</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>is designed to
  generate total shareholder return on average of 8.0% to 10.0% over a rolling
  three to five</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>year time period. In 2012, annual
  earnings per diluted share growth are expected to be higher than this</FONT>
  <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>due to a combination of the benefit of the 53rd week,
  a lower expected LIFO charge, the benefit of our</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>share buyback program during 2011, the benefits from the pension plan
  consolidation and the benefit</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>from Express
  Scripts prescription transfers.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>For 2012, we intend to continue to focus on
  improving sales growth, in accordance with our Customer</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>1st strategy, by making investments in gross margin and
  customer shopping experiences. We expect to</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>finance these investments primarily with operating cost reductions. We
  expect FIFO non-fuel operating</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>margins for 2012
  to expand slightly compared to 2011, excluding the UFCW consolidated pension
  plan</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>charge in 2011.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>For 2012, we expect our annualized LIFO charge to
  be approximately $140 million to $190 million. This</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>forecast is based on estimated cost changes for products in our
  inventory.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>For 2012, we expect interest expense to be
  approximately $450 million.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>We plan to use cash flow primarily for capital
  investments, to maintain our current debt coverage ratios,</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>to pay cash dividends, and to repurchase stock. As market
  conditions change, we re-evaluate these uses</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>of
  cash flow.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>We expect to obtain sales growth from new square
  footage, as well as from increased productivity from</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>existing locations.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Capital expenditures reflect our strategy of
  growth through expansion, as well as focusing on productivity</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>increases from our existing store base through remodels. In
  addition, we intend to continue our</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>emphasis on
  self-development and ownership of real estate, and logistics and technology
  improvements.</FONT><BR><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>The continued capital spending
  in technology is focused on improving store operations, logistics,</FONT>
  <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>manufacturing procurement, category management,
  merchandising and buying practices, and should</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>reduce merchandising costs. We intend to continue using cash flow from
  operations to finance capital</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>expenditure
  requirements. We expect capital investments for 2012 to be in the range of
  $1.9-$2.2 billion,</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>excluding acquisitions and
  purchases of leased facilities. We expect total food store square footage
  to</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>grow approximately 1.3%-1.5% before
  acquisitions and operational closings.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Based on current operating trends, we believe that
  cash flow from operations and other sources of</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>liquidity, including borrowings under our commercial paper program and
  bank credit facility, will be</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>adequate to meet
  anticipated requirements for working capital, capital expenditures, interest
  payments</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>and scheduled principal payments for
  the foreseeable future. We also believe we have adequate coverage</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>of our debt covenants to continue to respond effectively to
  competitive conditions.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>We believe we have adequate sources of cash, if
  needed, under our credit facility and other borrowing</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>sources for the next twelve months and for the foreseeable future
  beyond the next twelve months.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>We expect that our OG&amp;A results will be
  affected by increased costs, such as higher employee benefit</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>costs and credit card fees, offset by improved productivity
  from process changes and leverage gained</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>through sales increases.</FONT> </LI></UL>
<P align=center><B><FONT face="Times New Roman">A-23</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>

<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>
<UL style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt"><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>We expect that our effective tax rate for 2012
  will be approximately 36.5%, excluding the effect of the</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>resolution of any tax issues.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>We expect rent expense, as a percentage of total
  sales and excluding closed-store activity, will decrease</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>due to the emphasis our current strategy places on ownership
  of real estate.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>We believe that in 2012 there will be
  opportunities to reduce our operating costs in such areas as</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>administration, productivity improvements, shrink,
  warehousing and transportation. We intend to invest</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>most of these savings in our core business to drive profitable sales
  growth and offer improved value and</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>shopping
  experiences for our customers.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Although we are not required to make cash
  contributions to the Company-sponsored defined benefit</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>pension plans during 2012, we expect to contribute approximately $75
  million to these plans in 2012. We</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>expect any
  elective contributions made during 2012 will decrease our required
  contributions in future</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>years. Among other
  things, investment performance of plan assets, the interest rates required to
  be used</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>to calculate the pension obligations,
  and future changes in legislation, will determine the amounts of</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>any additional contributions. We expect 2012 expense for
  Company-sponsored defined benefit pension</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>plans
  to be approximately $90 million. In addition, we expect 401(k) Retirement
  Savings Account Plan</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>cash contributions and
  expense from automatic and matching contributions to participants to
  increase</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>slightly in 2012, compared to
  2011.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>We expect to contribute approximately $240 million
  to multi-employer pension plans in 2012, subject to</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>collective bargaining. In addition, we expect meaningful increases in
  expense as a result of increases in</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>multi-employer pension plan contributions over the next few
  years.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>We do not anticipate additional goodwill
  impairments in 2012.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>We have various labor agreements that will be
  renegotiated in 2012, covering store employees in</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Memphis, Las Vegas, Dayton and Columbus, Ohio, Indianapolis,
  Louisville, Nashville, Phoenix and</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Portland.
  Upon the expiration of our collective bargaining agreements, work stoppages by
  the affected</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>workers could occur if we are
  unable to negotiate new contracts with labor unions. A prolonged work</FONT>
  <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>stoppage affecting a substantial number of locations
  could have a material adverse effect on our results. </FONT><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>In all of these contracts, rising health care and pension costs will
  continue to be an important issue</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>in
  negotiations.</FONT><BR><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>&nbsp;<BR>Various
  uncertainties and other factors could cause us to fail to achieve our goals.
  These include:</FONT><BR>&nbsp;
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>The extent to which our sources of liquidity are
  sufficient to meet our requirements may be affected by</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>the state of the financial markets and the effect that such condition
  has on our ability to issue commercial</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>paper at
  acceptable rates. Our ability to borrow under our committed lines of credit,
  including our bank</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>credit facilities, could be
  impaired if one or more of our lenders under those lines is unwilling or
  unable</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>to honor its contractual obligation to
  lend to us.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Changes in market conditions could affect our cash
  flow.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Our ability to achieve sales and earnings goals
  may be affected by: labor negotiations or disputes;</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>industry consolidation; pricing and promotional activities of existing
  and new competitors, including</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>non-traditional
  competitors, and the aggressiveness of that competition; our response to these
  actions;</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>the state of the economy, including
  interest rates, the inflationary and deflationary trends in certain</FONT>
  <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>commodities, and the unemployment rate; the effect
  that increased fuel costs have on consumer</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>spending; changes in government-funded benefit programs; manufacturing
  commodity costs; diesel fuel</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>costs related to
  our logistics operations; trends in consumer spending; the extent to which our
  customers</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>exercise caution in their purchasing
  in response to economic conditions; the inconsistent pace of the</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>economic recovery; changes in inflation or deflation in
  product and operating costs; stock repurchases;</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>the effect of brand prescription drugs going off patent; our ability to
  obtain additional pharmacy sales</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>from third
  party payors such as Express Scripts; the benefits that we receive from the
  consolidation of</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>the UFCW pension plans and the
  success of our future growth plans. Our ability to achieve sales and</FONT>
  <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>earnings goals may also be affected by our ability to
  manage the factors identified above.</FONT> </LI></UL>
<P align=center><B><FONT face="Times New Roman">A-24</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>

<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>
<UL style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt"><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>The extent to which the adjustments we are making
  to our strategy create value for our shareholders will</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>depend primarily on the reaction of our customers and our competitors
  to these adjustments, as well</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>as operating
  conditions, including inflation or deflation, increased competitive activity,
  and cautious</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>spending behavior of our
  customers.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Our product cost inflation could vary from our
  estimate due to general economic conditions, weather,</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>availability of raw materials and ingredients in the products that we
  sell and their packaging, and other</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>factors
  beyond our control.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Our ability to pass on product cost increases will
  depend on the reactions of our customers and</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>competitors to those increases.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Our ability to use free cash flow to continue to
  maintain our debt coverage and to reward our shareholders</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>could be affected by unanticipated increases in net total
  debt, our inability to generate free cash flow at</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>the levels anticipated, and our failure to generate expected
  earnings.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Our LIFO charge and the timing of our recognition
  of LIFO expense will be affected primarily by changes</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>in product costs during the year.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>If actual results differ significantly from
  anticipated future results for certain reporting units including</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>variable interest entities, an impairment loss for any
  excess of the carrying value of the reporting units&#146;</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>goodwill over the implied fair value would have to be
  recognized.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>In addition to the factors identified above, our
  identical store sales growth could be affected by increases</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>in Kroger private label sales, the effect of our &#147;sister
  stores&#148; (new stores opened in close proximity to an</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>existing store) and reductions in retail pricing.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Our operating margins, without fuel, could decline
  or fail to meet expectations if we are unable to pass</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>on any cost increases, if we fail to deliver the cost savings
  contemplated or if changes in the cost of our</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>inventory and the timing of those changes differ from our
  expectations.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>We have estimated our exposure to the claims and
  litigation arising in the normal course of business,</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>as well as to the material litigation facing Kroger, and believe we
  have made provisions where it is</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>reasonably
  possible to estimate and where an adverse outcome is probable. Unexpected
  outcomes in</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>these matters, however, could
  result in an adverse effect on our earnings.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Consolidation in the food industry is likely to
  continue and the effects on our business, either favorable</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>or unfavorable, cannot be foreseen.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Rent expense, which includes subtenant rental
  income, could be adversely affected by the state of the</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>economy, increased store closure activity and future
  consolidation.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Depreciation expense, which includes the
  amortization of assets recorded under capital leases, is</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>computed principally using the straight-line method over the
  estimated useful lives of individual assets,</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>or
  the remaining terms of leases. Use of the straight-line method of depreciation
  creates a risk that future</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>asset write-offs or
  potential impairment charges related to store closings would be larger than if
  an</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>accelerated method of depreciation were
  followed.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Our effective tax rate may differ from the
  expected rate due to changes in laws, the status of pending</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>items with various taxing authorities, and the deductibility
  of certain expenses.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>The actual amount of automatic and matching cash
  contributions to our 401(k) Retirement Savings</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Account Plan will depend on the number of participants, savings rate,
  compensation as defined by the</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>plan, and length
  of service of participants.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>The amounts of our contributions and recorded
  expense related to multi-employer pension funds could</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>vary from the amounts that we expect, and could increase more than
  anticipated. Should asset values in</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>these funds
  deteriorate, if employers withdraw from these funds without providing for
  their share of the</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>liability, or should our
  estimates prove to be understated, our contributions could increase more
  rapidly</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>than we have anticipated.</FONT>
</LI></UL>
<P align=center><B><FONT face="Times New Roman">A-25</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>

<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>
<UL style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt"><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>If volatility in the financial markets continues
  or worsens, our contributions to Company-sponsored</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>defined benefit pension plans could increase more than anticipated in
  future years.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Changes in laws or regulations, including changes
  in accounting standards, taxation requirements and</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>environmental laws may have a material effect on our financial
  statements.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Changes in the general business and economic
  conditions in our operating regions may affect the</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>shopping habits of our customers, which could affect sales and
  earnings.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Changes in our product mix may negatively affect
  certain financial indicators. For example, we continue</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>to add supermarket fuel centers to our store base. Since gasoline
  generates low profit margins, we</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>expect to see
  our FIFO gross profit margins decline as gasoline sales increase. Although
  this negatively</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>affects our FIFO gross margin,
  gasoline sales provide a positive effect on OG&amp;A expense as a
  percentage</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>of sales.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Our capital expenditures, expected square footage
  growth, and number of store projects completed</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>over the next fiscal year could differ from our estimate if we are
  unsuccessful in acquiring suitable sites</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>for
  new stores, if development costs vary from those budgeted, if our logistics
  and technology or store</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>projects are not
  completed on budget or within the time frame projected, or if economic
  conditions fail</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>to improve, or
  worsen.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Interest expense could be adversely affected by
  the interest rate environment, changes in our credit</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>ratings, fluctuations in the amount of outstanding debt, decisions to
  incur prepayment penalties on the</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>early
  redemption of debt and any factor that adversely affects our operations and
  results in an increase</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>in
debt.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Impairment losses, including goodwill, could be
  affected by changes in our assumptions of future cash</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>flows, market values or business valuations in the market. Our cash
  flow projections include several</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>years of
  projected cash flows which would be affected by changes in the economic
  environment, real</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>estate market values,
  competitive activity, inflation and customer behavior.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Our estimated expense and obligation for
  Kroger-sponsored pension plans and other post-retirement</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>benefits could be affected by changes in the assumptions
  used in calculating those amounts. These</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>assumptions include, among others, the discount rate, the expected
  long-term rate of return on plan</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>assets,
  average life expectancy and the rate of increases in compensation and health
  care costs.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Adverse weather conditions could increase the cost
  our suppliers charge for their products, or may</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>decrease customer demand for certain products. Increases in demand for
  certain commodities could</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>also increase the
  cost our suppliers charge for their products. Additionally, increases in the
  cost of</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>inputs, such as utility costs or raw
  material costs, could negatively affect financial ratios and
  earnings.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Although we presently operate only in the United
  States, civil unrest in foreign countries in which our</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>suppliers do business may affect the prices we are charged for imported
  goods. If we are unable to pass</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>on these
  increases to our customers, our FIFO gross margin and net earnings would
  suffer.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT>
  </LI><LI STYLE="text-align: justify"><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Earnings and sales also may be affected by adverse
  weather conditions, particularly to the extent that</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>hurricanes, tornadoes, floods, earthquakes, and other conditions
  disrupt our operations or those of our</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>suppliers; create shortages in the availability or increases in the
  cost of products that we sell in our stores</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>or
  materials and ingredients we use in our manufacturing facilities; or raise the
  cost of supplying energy</FONT> <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>to our various
  operations, including the cost of transportation.</FONT> </LI></UL>
<P align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Other factors
and assumptions not identified above could also cause actual results to differ
materially from those set forth in the forward-looking information. Accordingly,
actual events and results may vary significantly from those included in,
contemplated or implied by forward-looking statements made by us or our
representatives.</FONT></P>
<P align=center><B><FONT face="Times New Roman">A-26</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>

<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>
<P align=center><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>R</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>EPORT </FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>OF</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2> I</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>NDEPENDENT</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2> R</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>EGISTERED</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>
P</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>UBLIC<FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman">
</FONT></FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>A</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>CCOUNTING</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2> F</FONT></B><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=1>IRM</FONT></B></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>To the Shareowners and Board of
Directors of <BR>The Kroger Co.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>In our
opinion, the accompanying consolidated balance sheets and the related
consolidated statements of operations, cash flows and changes in shareowners&#146;
equity present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of The
Kroger Co. and its subsidiaries at January 28, 2012 and January 29, 2011, and
the results of their operations and their cash flows for each of the three years
in the period ended January 28, 2012</FONT><B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>
</FONT></B><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>in conformity with accounting principles
generally accepted in the United States of America. Also in our opinion, the
Company maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over
financial reporting as of January 28, 2012, based on criteria established in
</FONT><I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Internal Control - Integrated
Framework</FONT></I><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2> issued by the Committee of
Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO). The Company&#146;s
management is responsible for these financial statements, for maintaining
effective internal control over financial reporting and for its assessment of
the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting, included in
Management&#146;s Report on Internal Control over Financial Reporting appearing on
page A-1. Our responsibility is to express opinions on these financial
statements and on the Company&#146;s internal control over financial reporting based
on our integrated audits. We conducted our audits in accordance with the
standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
Those standards require that we plan and perform the audits to obtain reasonable
assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material
misstatement and whether effective internal control over financial reporting was
maintained in all material respects. Our audits of the financial statements
included examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and
disclosures in the financial statements, assessing the accounting principles
used and significant estimates made by management, and evaluating the overall
financial statement presentation. Our audit of internal control over financial
reporting included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial
reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, and testing and
evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on
the assessed risk. Our audits also included performing such other procedures as
we considered necessary in the circumstances. We believe that our audits provide
a reasonable basis for our opinions.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>A company&#146;s internal control over financial reporting is a process
designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial
reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in
accordance with generally accepted accounting principles. A company&#146;s internal
control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (i)
pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and
fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company;
(ii) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to
permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted
accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are
being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of
the company; and (iii) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or
timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the
company&#146;s assets that could have a material effect on the financial
statements.</FONT></P>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2><FONT size=3 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial
reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements. Also, projections of any
evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that
controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the
degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may
deteriorate.</FONT></P><IMG src="annual_report3x8x1.jpg" border=0> <BR>
<P align=justify><FONT face="Times New Roman" size=2>Cincinnati, Ohio <BR>March 27,
2012</FONT></P>
<P align=center><B><FONT face="Times New Roman">A-27</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>

<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>
